title: Provides that the division of criminal justice services provide statistics as to witnesses in court proceedings that have been threatened, attacked or killed
summary: Provides that the division of criminal justice services collect statistics as to witnesses in court proceedings that have been threatened, attacked or killed and requires police chiefs, county sheriffs and the superintendent of the state police to submit such statistics and report to the division of criminal justice services on or before January 15th of each calendar year.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1664

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the executive law, in relation to compiling statistics on court
witnesses that have been threatened, attacked or killed

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
This bill would require the NYS Division of Criminal Justice Services
to provide statistics as to witnesses in court proceedings that have
been threatened, attacked or killed.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
Add; new section 837s to the executive law that requires police
chiefs, county sheriff and the.Superintendent of the State Police to
submit a report to the division of every threat, attack or death of
a witness in a court proceeding investigated by his or her law
enforcement agency during the previous calendar year. These reports
must be submitted to the division on or before January 15th of each
calendar year.

Requires the Division of Criminal Justice Services to complete a
report on or before March 1st of each calendar year that that
includes all reports filed pursuant to subdivision 1 of this
legislation. Requires that such reports shall be submitted to the
Governor, President Pro Tern of the Senate and the Speaker of the
Assembly. Such report shall include the number of threats, attacks
and deaths committed against witnesses in court proceedings as well
as whether or not the threat, attack or death was committed by a
person who was a party to the proceeding or by a person associated
with a person who was a party to the proceeding.

EFFECTS OF PRESENT LAW WHICH THIS BILL WOULD ALTER:
There is currently no requirement that the Division of Criminal
Justice Services compile reports regarding witnesses in court
proceedings who have been threatened, attacked or killed.

JUSTIFICATION:
Many individuals who have been witnesses to crimes in New York have
been coerced into silence through intimidation or violence by those
they are testifying against or by their associates. Others witnesses
have been murdered. In one particular case, Bobby Gibson, a witness
to a murder was himself gunned down in Brooklyn. After his murder,
numerous witnesses refused to testify or went into hiding. New York
must address the problem of violence against, intimidation of, or
harassment of witnesses. If witnesses are not protected they may
refuse to testify in court proceedings and this would impair the
functioning and integrity of our judicial system. We must do our
utmost to protect witnesses in all court proceedings in the State of
New York. The first step toward ensuring protection for people who
testify in our courts is to fully understand the extent of the

problem so that it can be addressed by the Legislature and the
Governor through further legislation. This bill will allow New York
to gage the extent of the problem of witnesses being threatened,
attacked or killed.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
S.3116 of 2007
S.88 of 2009
01/07/09 REFERRED TO FINANCE
01/06/10 REFERRED TO FINANCE

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS FOR STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the 120th day after it shall have
become a law, provided that any procedure, rules and/or regulations
necessary to implement the provisions of this act on its effective
date are authorized and directed to be completed on or before such
date.
